content.title: VTE Prophylaxis in the ICU
content.summary: Venous thromboembolism prophylaxis is a cornerstone of ICU care, with critically ill patients having significantly elevated DVT and PE risk due to immobility, inflammation, central lines, and mechanical ventilation, requiring systematic risk assessment and appropriate pharmacological or mechanical prophylaxis.
key_points: ICU patients have 10-30% DVT incidence without prophylaxis; PE is leading preventable cause of hospital death
Pharmacologic prophylaxis preferred: LMWH or UFH; fondaparinux in HIT
Mechanical prophylaxis (SCDs) when bleeding risk precludes anticoagulation
Combination pharmacologic + mechanical may benefit highest-risk patients
Daily reassessment for contraindications and appropriateness of prophylaxis type
Consider extended prophylaxis in prolonged immobility or ongoing high-risk conditions
content.statement: Venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis in critically ill patients is an essential preventive measure, requiring systematic assessment of thrombotic and bleeding risks to select appropriate pharmacological (LMWH or UFH) and/or mechanical (intermittent pneumatic compression) prophylaxis, with ongoing reassessment as patient status changes.

explanation.intuition: ICU patients are the perfect storm for blood clots: they're immobile, often sedated, have inflammatory conditions, central venous catheters, and may have underlying hypercoagulable states from sepsis or malignancy. Without prophylaxis, DVT rates can exceed 30%. Yet these same patients often have bleeding risks requiring careful balance.
explanation.key_insight: The key is not whether to give prophylaxis but which type and when. Most ICU patients should receive pharmacologic prophylaxis unless actively bleeding or at very high bleeding risk. The daily assessment should focus on when to transition from mechanical to pharmacologic prophylaxis as bleeding risk resolves.
explanation.technical_details: LMWH (enoxaparin 40mg SC daily or 30mg BID; dalteparin 5000 units daily) offers predictable anticoagulation without routine monitoring. UFH (5000 units SC BID or TID) allows rapid reversal and doesn't require renal dose adjustment. SCDs reduce DVT by 50% vs no prophylaxis but are inferior to pharmacologic prophylaxis. Anti-Xa monitoring may be useful in obesity or renal dysfunction.

definitions_glossary.venous_thromboembolism: Spectrum including deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism from venous blood clot formation
definitions_glossary.pharmacologic_prophylaxis: Anticoagulant medications given at prophylactic doses to prevent clot formation
definitions_glossary.mechanical_prophylaxis: Physical devices (SCDs, GCS) preventing venous stasis and promoting blood flow
definitions_glossary.low_molecular_weight_heparin: Fractionated heparin with predictable anticoagulation, once or twice daily dosing
definitions_glossary.unfractionated_heparin: Standard heparin given subcutaneously for prophylaxis; short half-life allows rapid reversal
definitions_glossary.intermittent_pneumatic_compression: Sequential compression devices on legs mimicking calf muscle pump to prevent stasis
definitions_glossary.graduated_compression_stockings: Elastic stockings providing gradient pressure to promote venous return
definitions_glossary.virchow_triad: Classic triad of thrombosis risk: stasis, endothelial injury, and hypercoagulability
definitions_glossary.bleeding_risk_assessment: Evaluation of factors increasing hemorrhage risk that may contraindicate anticoagulation
definitions_glossary.extended_prophylaxis: Continuation of VTE prophylaxis after hospital discharge in high-risk patients
definitions_glossary.heparin_induced_thrombocytopenia: Immune-mediated complication of heparin requiring alternative anticoagulants
definitions_glossary.anti_xa_monitoring: Laboratory test measuring anticoagulant effect of LMWH; used in special populations

virchow_triad_in_icu.stasis: Immobility from sedation, paralysis, mechanical ventilation; bed rest
virchow_triad_in_icu.endothelial_injury: Central venous catheters, trauma, surgery, inflammation
virchow_triad_in_icu.hypercoagulability: Sepsis-induced coagulopathy, malignancy, dehydration, inflammatory states

pathophysiology.risk_amplification: ICU factors multiply baseline VTE risk: surgery, trauma, sepsis, immobility, and lines all contribute
pathophysiology.consequences: Untreated DVT leads to PE in 30-50%; PE is leading preventable cause of hospital death

bleeding_risk_factors: Active bleeding or recent major hemorrhage
risk_assessment.risk_stratification: Most ICU patients are high VTE risk; focus assessment on bleeding risk to determine prophylaxis type

lmwh.agents: Enoxaparin 40mg SC daily or 30mg BID; dalteparin 5000 units SC daily
lmwh.advantages: Predictable effect, once-daily dosing, lower HIT risk than UFH
lmwh.monitoring: Anti-Xa levels in renal dysfunction, obesity, pregnancy
lmwh.renal_adjustment: Reduce dose or use UFH when CrCl <30 mL/min

ufh.advantages: Short half-life, reversible with protamine, no renal adjustment needed
ufh.disadvantages: Less predictable, higher HIT risk, requires more frequent dosing
ufh.indications: Renal failure, high bleeding risk requiring rapid reversal capability

fondaparinux.cautions: Long half-life, renal elimination, not reversible

ipcs_scds.mechanism: Sequential compression mimics calf pump, increases venous flow velocity
ipcs_scds.efficacy: Reduces DVT by ~50% vs no prophylaxis; inferior to pharmacologic
ipcs_scds.requirements: Proper fit, continuous use except for ambulation

gcs.efficacy: Modest benefit; usually combined with other methods
gcs.cautions: Ensure proper sizing; contraindicated in arterial insufficiency

combination.indications: Highest-risk patients (major trauma, spinal cord injury)
combination.evidence: Some studies show additional benefit; others show no difference

implementation.initiation: Start prophylaxis within 24 hours of ICU admission unless contraindicated

daily_assessment.bleeding_status: Active bleeding? Recent procedure? Platelet count? Coagulation status?
daily_assessment.transition: When bleeding risk resolves, transition from mechanical to pharmacologic prophylaxis
daily_assessment.hold_criteria: Major surgery, invasive procedure, active hemorrhage - hold pharmacologic, use mechanical

special_populations.renal_failure: Use UFH or dose-adjusted LMWH with anti-Xa monitoring
special_populations.obesity: Consider higher LMWH doses (enoxaparin 40mg BID) or weight-based dosing
special_populations.hit: Fondaparinux or direct thrombin inhibitor for prophylaxis
special_populations.spinal_epidural: Coordinate anticoagulation timing with anesthesia for catheter placement/removal

monitoring_outcomes.process_measures: Prophylaxis administration rate, appropriate selection, documentation
monitoring_outcomes.bundle_compliance: VTE prophylaxis is core element of ICU quality bundles (ABCDEF)

skos.definition: Systematic prevention of venous thromboembolism in critically ill patients through risk assessment and appropriate pharmacological and/or mechanical prophylaxis measures.

learning_objectives: Identify ICU-specific risk factors for venous thromboembolism
Compare pharmacologic and mechanical prophylaxis options
Apply appropriate prophylaxis selection based on bleeding risk
Describe daily reassessment protocol for VTE prophylaxis
Recognize special populations requiring modified prophylaxis approaches
Integrate VTE prophylaxis into ICU quality improvement bundles
clinical_pearls: Most ICU patients are high VTE risk - the question is not IF but HOW to provide prophylaxis
Mechanical prophylaxis is a bridge, not a destination - transition to pharmacologic when bleeding risk allows
LMWH is preferred over UFH for most patients due to lower HIT risk and convenience
SCDs only work when worn - ensure proper fit and compliance
Don't forget to restart anticoagulation prophylaxis after procedures - common oversight
Anti-Xa monitoring may be useful in extremes of weight or renal function

board_yield.usmle_step1: Virchow's triad, heparin mechanisms, coagulation cascade
board_yield.usmle_step2: Prophylaxis selection, dosing, contraindications, HIT recognition
board_yield.abim_critical_care: Special populations, extended prophylaxis, failure workup

common_misconceptions: Misconception: SCDs are adequate prophylaxis for ICU patients. Reality: Pharmacologic prophylaxis is superior; SCDs are for when anticoagulation contraindicated
Misconception: All anticoagulants are equivalent for prophylaxis. Reality: LMWH preferred; UFH for renal failure; fondaparinux for HIT
Misconception: Prophylaxis can be held indefinitely for procedures. Reality: Resume as soon as bleeding risk allows; prolonged holds increase VTE risk
